entry.title: Simulating a Mortality Dataset in R Studio
entry.summary:
Simulating a Mortality Dataset in R Studio¶

Overview¶

In this post I will show you how to simulate a large dataset of mortality claims. Sometimes it is useful to use simulated data. For example, if you wanted to experiment with new modelling techniques pertaining to a specific problem, but were unable to find a useful dataset, it may be easiest just to create your own. Alternatively, you may simply wish to supplement existing data with simulated data. If you have some assumptions about the variables you wish to create, it's possible to create entire datasets from scratch.

.highlight .k { color: #008000; font-weight: bold } /* Keyword */
.highlight .o { color: #666666 } /* Operator */

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Simulating-a-Mortality-Dataset-in-R-Studio">Simulating a Mortality Dataset in R Studio<a class="anchor-link" href="#Simulating-a-Mortality-Dataset-in-R-Studio">¶</a></h1>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Overview">Overview<a class="anchor-link" href="#Overview">¶</a></h2><p>In this post I will show you how to simulate a large dataset of mortality claims. Sometimes it is useful to use simulated data. For example, if you wanted to experiment with new modelling techniques pertaining to a specific problem, but were unable to find a useful dataset, it may be easiest just to create your own. Alternatively, you may simply wish to supplement existing data with simulated data. If you have some assumptions about the variables you wish to create, it's possible to create entire datasets from scratch.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Example">Example<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example">¶</a></h2><p>Imagine that you wanted to experiment with fitting different predictive models to life insurance claims data (perhaps to practice your coding skills or to explore an idea) but didn't have all the data required. Rather than spend time searching for or collecting large volumes of data appropriate for your specific problem, you could simply (and quickly) create a simulated dataset.</p>
<p>I will show you how to create a dataset representing a portfolio of lives with lump sum life insurance cover, but the following techniques can be used to create all sorts of data. We will end up with a large dataset where each row will represent one life and the columns will contain information about that persons age, salary, occupation, gender, location and, finally, whether or not that person died during a specific period.</p>
<p>In order to do this we will need to come up with some assumptions about the variables we wish to create. The assumptions I will make will be very simple and are listed below.</p>
<div class="alert alert-block alert-info">***Age***: Normally distributed with mean age = 40 and variance = 25
<br />
***Gender***: 40% of the sample will be Male, 60% female
<br />
***Occupation***: 3 categories representing different occupations. 50% of the lives will be in category 1, 20% in category 2 and 30% in category 3
<br />
***Location***: 4 categories representing different areas of residence. 10% will be in category 1, 20% in category 2, 50% in category 3 and 20% in category 4
<br />
***Salary***: Gamma distributed. I will assume that salary varies by age and occupation
<br />
***Exposure***: This variable represents the length of time (in years) that each person was covered for. This will come from a uniform(0,3) distribution (i.e the maximum cover period is 3 years)
<br />
***Claim***: I will assume that the probability of death is a formula linked to age and occupation. The base level of mortality will be $\frac{Age}{20000}$. Mortality increases by 20% for those in occupation category 1 and by 15% for those living in locations 3 or 4</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Creating-the-data-in-R-Studio">Creating the data in R Studio<a class="anchor-link" href="#Creating-the-data-in-R-Studio">¶</a></h2><h3 id="Setting-Assumptions">Setting Assumptions<a class="anchor-link" href="#Setting-Assumptions">¶</a></h3><p>I will assume you have R Studio installed and some experience with basic R programming. If you have not used R before, I recommend visiting <a href="https://www.datacamp.com">https://www.datacamp.com</a> and taking the free intro to R course. We will be using the simstudy package. If you have not yet installed this package, run <code>install.packages('simstudy')</code> to do so.</p>
<p>Simstudy first requires us to generate a table containing our assumptions. Each row in this table will contain information relating to one of our variables. We will need to specify a name for each variable, the distribution we wish to simulate from and formula for the mean of each variable (and in some cases, variance). To create the assumptions data, use the <code>defData()</code> function.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [31]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># load library</span>
<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>simstudy<span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kp">set.seed</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">123</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># initialise our assumptions table and add the Age variable</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Age'</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'normal'</span><span class="p">,</span> formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">40</span><span class="p">,</span> variance <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">25</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># the assumptions table has now been created and can be viewed</span>
def
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table>
<thead><tr><th scope="col">varname</th><th scope="col">formula</th><th scope="col">variance</th><th scope="col">dist</th><th scope="col">link</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Age     </td><td>40      </td><td>25      </td><td>normal  </td><td>identity</td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To add to this table, use the <code>defData()</code> function again, but this time specifying the name of the table we've just created using the <code>dtDefs</code> argument. For example, add the gender, occupation, location and exposure variables as follows:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># add a binary variable to indicate gender - 40% of lives will be Male and will be represented by as 1's</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>dtDefs <span class="o">=</span> def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Gender"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"binary"</span><span class="p">,</span> formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0.4</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># add a categorical variable to define occupation type - there will be three classes</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>dtDefs <span class="o">=</span> def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Occupation"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"categorical"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"0.5;0.2;0.3"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># add the location variable to the data table</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>dtDefs <span class="o">=</span> def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Location"</span><span class="p">,</span>dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"categorical"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"0.1;0.2;0.5;0.2"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># add a variable to indicate 'exposure years' - in other words, the length of time</span>
<span class="c1"># an individual was insured</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>def<span class="p">,</span> varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Exposure'</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"uniform"</span><span class="p">,</span> formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"0;3"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># the assumptions table now looks like:</span>
def
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table>
<thead><tr><th scope="col">varname</th><th scope="col">formula</th><th scope="col">variance</th><th scope="col">dist</th><th scope="col">link</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Age            </td><td>40             </td><td>25             </td><td>normal         </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Gender         </td><td>0.4            </td><td> 0             </td><td>binary         </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Occupation     </td><td>0.5;0.2;0.3    </td><td> 0             </td><td>categorical    </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location       </td><td>0.1;0.2;0.5;0.2</td><td> 0             </td><td>categorical    </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Exposure       </td><td>0;3            </td><td> 0             </td><td>uniform        </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Since salary and claim depend on other variables, the 'formula' argument for these variables will be a bit more complicated. I have used the <code>paste()</code> function to specify the formulas to be passed into <code>defData()</code>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># add a salary variable - the mean of which will increase with age and will vary by occupation class</span>
<span class="c1"># use a gamma distribution</span>

salary_formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">paste</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"ifelse(Occupation == 1, Age * 800, </span>
<span class="s">                        ifelse(Occupation == 2, Age * 1200, Age * 1350))"</span><span class="p">)</span>

def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Salary"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"gamma"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> salary_formula<span class="p">,</span>variance <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0.2</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Now, add the binary claim indicator - the probability of death varies as specified earlier</span>
claim_formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">paste</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"(Age * 1/20000)"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                      <span class="s">" * ifelse(Occupation == 1,1.2,1)"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                      <span class="s">" * ifelse(Location %in% c(3,4), 1.15,1)"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                      sep <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">""</span><span class="p">)</span>

def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>def<span class="p">,</span> varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Claim"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"binary"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> claim_formula<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># the final assumptions table now looks like:</span>
def
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table>
<thead><tr><th scope="col">varname</th><th scope="col">formula</th><th scope="col">variance</th><th scope="col">dist</th><th scope="col">link</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Age                                                                                                          </td><td>40                                                                                                           </td><td>25.0                                                                                                         </td><td>normal                                                                                                       </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Gender                                                                                                       </td><td>0.4                                                                                                          </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>binary                                                                                                       </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Occupation                                                                                                   </td><td>0.5;0.2;0.3                                                                                                  </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>categorical                                                                                                  </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location                                                                                                     </td><td>0.1;0.2;0.5;0.2                                                                                              </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>categorical                                                                                                  </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Exposure                                                                                                     </td><td>0;3                                                                                                          </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>uniform                                                                                                      </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Salary                                                                                                       </td><td>ifelse(Occupation == 1, Age * 800, 
                        ifelse(Occupation == 2, Age * 1200, Age * 1350))</td><td> 0.2                                                                                                         </td><td>gamma                                                                                                        </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Claim                                                                                                        </td><td>(Age * 1/20000) * ifelse(Occupation == 1,1.2,1) * ifelse(Location %in% c(3,4), 1.15,1)                       </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>binary                                                                                                       </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Generating-the-Data">Generating the Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Generating-the-Data">¶</a></h3><p>Now, actually generating the data is easy. Do this using the <code>genData()</code> function. The first argument, n, is how many records you want to simulate. Then just pass in the name of the assumptions table. I will simulate 1.5m records.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># simulate 1.5m records</span>
dt <span class="o">=</span> genData<span class="p">(</span>n <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">1500000</span><span class="p">,</span>def<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># view the first few rows</span>
<span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table>
<thead><tr><th scope="col">id</th><th scope="col">Age</th><th scope="col">Gender</th><th scope="col">Occupation</th><th scope="col">Location</th><th scope="col">Exposure</th><th scope="col">Salary</th><th scope="col">Claim</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>1        </td><td>40.35751 </td><td>0        </td><td>1        </td><td>3        </td><td>1.4130421</td><td>41917.01 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>2        </td><td>38.42680 </td><td>1        </td><td>3        </td><td>3        </td><td>0.7729843</td><td>48341.37 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>3        </td><td>36.94120 </td><td>0        </td><td>3        </td><td>1        </td><td>1.0042294</td><td>59266.96 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>4        </td><td>44.37291 </td><td>0        </td><td>1        </td><td>3        </td><td>1.0468063</td><td>23435.46 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>5        </td><td>36.91328 </td><td>1        </td><td>2        </td><td>3        </td><td>0.7588958</td><td>57663.62 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>6        </td><td>46.14252 </td><td>1        </td><td>1        </td><td>3        </td><td>2.3525461</td><td>76501.43 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Exploring-the-Simulated-Data">Exploring the Simulated Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Exploring-the-Simulated-Data">¶</a></h3><p>Now, we can summarise and visualise the dataset that has been created to check that everything is as expected. The <code>summary()</code> and <code>table()</code> functions are very useful and the ggplot2 library is particularly good for creating visualisations. Use the <code>ggplot()</code> function to create density plots, bar charts and scatter plots to check that distributions have been created according to our specified assumptions and to check the relationships between variables. If you have not installed ggplot2, execute <code>install.packages('ggplot2')</code></p>
<p>First, use <code>summary()</code> to see statistics for the entire dataset. Then use <code>table()</code> and <code>prop.table()</code> to see how claims vary by occupation and location.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [27]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Summary stats</span>
<span class="kp">summary</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Claims by Occupation/Location"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Occupation</span>
<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Occupation"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kp">table</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Occupation<span class="p">,</span> dt<span class="o">$</span>Claim<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Location"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kp">table</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Location<span class="p">,</span> dt<span class="o">$</span>Claim<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># prop table can be used to convert the tables above to percentages</span>
<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Occupation"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kp">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">prop.table</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">table</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Occupation<span class="p">,</span> dt<span class="o">$</span>Claim<span class="p">),</span> margin<span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">1</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="m">5</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Location"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kp">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">prop.table</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">table</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Location<span class="p">,</span> dt<span class="o">$</span>Claim<span class="p">),</span> margin<span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">1</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="m">5</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Next, we can use density plots to check that ages are normally distributed and that salaries are a) gamma distributed and b) vary by occupation.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>ggplot2<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># view distribution of ages</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x<span class="o">=</span>Age<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_density<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> theme_bw<span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It looks like age has been simulated as expected. The curve is bell shaped, the mean age is clearly 40 and most people are aged between 30 - 50, which is also in line with expectations given the variance we specified. To check that salary has been correctly simulated, repeat the <code>ggplot()</code> function but replace Age with Salary in the <code>aes()</code> (aesthetic) argument. We will also include an additional argument - <code>facet_wrap()</code> - to generate different density plots for each occupation group.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># view distribution of salary by occupation class</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> Salary<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
  geom_density<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
  facet_wrap<span class="p">(</span><span class="o">~</span>Occupation<span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
  theme_bw<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span>
ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Salary Dist. by Occupation Category"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>These look like gamma distributions and salary seems to be highest for occupation category 3 - which is correct!</p>
<p>In our assumptions table we state that salary should increase with age. We can check this using a scatter plot. Use <code>ggplot()</code> again but with <code>geom_point()</code> instead of density. Also, add <code>y = Salary</code> to the aesthetic.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [24]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># plot sample of age against salary</span>
<span class="c1"># (plot first 1000 rows for a better visual. 'pch = 21' controls the type of point)</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">[</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="m">1000</span><span class="p">,],</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> Age<span class="p">,</span> y <span class="o">=</span> Salary<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_point<span class="p">(</span>pch <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">21</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> theme_bw<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Age/Salary Scatter"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Finally, view a bar chart showing counts of each location category. This time use <code>geom_bar()</code> and add <code>facet_wrap()</code> to view separate bar charts for each occupation class.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># distribution of locations by occupation</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span>Location<span class="p">)))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_bar<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> theme_bw<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
  facet_wrap<span class="p">(</span><span class="o">~</span>Occupation<span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
xlab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Location"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Location by Occupation Category"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Creating-new-Features">Creating new Features<a class="anchor-link" href="#Creating-new-Features">¶</a></h3><p>This last section will demonstrate how we could add some simple extra features to the dataset. These new features will be created using existing variables. Currently, age is exact and so we have lots of unique values. To reduce the number of distinct values I will create an 'Age_Last' variable. In addition, sometimes it is useful to transform numerical variables to categorical and so I will show you how to create a 'Salary_Band' feature from the numerical salary variable. This will group salary into a number of different categories which we will treat as nominal(you may also wish to treat these as ordinal factors).</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># create an 'Age_Last' variable from Age exact that we simulated earlier</span>
dt<span class="o">$</span>Age_Last <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">floor</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Age<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># we can also create a categorical variable from the raw numeric </span>
<span class="c1"># salary variable - e.g group into bins</span>
<span class="c1"># We will create groups using a helper function and custom defined breaks</span>
<span class="c1"># Bins can include, for example, those earning <25k, 25-35k, 35-45k, 45-75k,75k+</span>
<span class="c1"># (I've just arbitrarily picked these)</span>

quant_bin <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kr">function</span><span class="p">(</span>x<span class="p">,</span> breaks<span class="p">){</span>
  bin <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">as.numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">cut</span><span class="p">(</span>x<span class="p">,</span>
                       breaks <span class="o">=</span> breaks<span class="p">,</span>
                       include.lowest <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">T</span><span class="p">,</span> right <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">T</span><span class="p">))</span>
  bin
<span class="p">}</span>

breaks <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">25000</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">35000</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">45000</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">75000</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kp">max</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Salary<span class="p">))</span>

dt<span class="o">$</span>Salary_Band <span class="o">=</span> quant_bin<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Salary<span class="p">,</span> breaks<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Now, view the first few rows of the data again</span>
<span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Summary">Summary<a class="anchor-link" href="#Summary">¶</a></h2><p>In summary, you should now be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Generate a table of assumptions</li>
<li>Simulate a large dataset using the assumptions table</li>
<li>Check summary statistics and visualise the data</li>
<li>Create some simple new features</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
